theSkullery

theSkullery
Your contribution
Submit
Over the years, I've tried dozens of recipe apps and services in an attempt to cook better and get more organized.
This website is my attempt at getting recipes organized and categorized by moving them from closed services and random handwritten pages to a more open, beautiful, and shareable place while having the convenience of plain-text.

For example, here's a recipe in plain text that I've implemented on this website.
Here's that recipe processed in theSkullery.net. The magic comes behind-the-scenes, with recipe microdata via schema.org. This process adds special tags around each bit of content, which is what lets the infrastructure behind (like Jekyll) read your recipes and render them in mere seconds in the browser.

This is definitely a work in progress. This project helped me learn and consolidate my knowledge with a lot of languages and apps (Jekyll, Ruby, SCSS, JavaScript, Netlify, Cloudflare, Google Firebase). The website might go down from time to time, or break, the recipes are here to stay, though, and nothing will get lost.

If you would like to submit your own recipe, please download a template, fill it in and upload it below. Also, please make sure not to upload files with the same name as they will be overwritten. In case you'd like to leave some feedback or want to submit recipes by URL, please use the form below.
If you would like to submit your own recipe, please download a template, fill it in and upload it below. Also, please make sure not to upload files with the same name as they will be overwritten.
*.txt and *.md only

About

theSkullery is all about simplicity, you do not have to log in to see the recipes, your browser is keeping tabs on your favorites, you can dynamically scale your recipes up or down, you can tick off where you are with your instructions, and you can copy all unchecked ingredients to your clipboard for when you go shopping.
I hope you find your inspiration here and cook something as amazing as you.

"Cooking is a craft, I like to think, and a good cook is a craftsman -- not an artist. There's nothing wrong with that: The great cathedrals of Europe were built by craftsmen -- though not designed by them. Practicing your craft in expert fashion is noble, honorable, and satisfying." --AB
